author: Winford Donald, Plag Ingo
title: Sranan structure dataset
booktitle: Atlas of Pidgin and Creole Language Structures Online
editor: Max Planck Institute for Evolutionary Anthropology
publisher: Max Planck Institute for Evolutionary Anthropology

content.srn: A mama fon a pikin.
content.en: The mother beat the child.

content.srn: A boi lobi a umapikin.
content.en: The boy loves the girl.

content.srn: A granman fu den Dyuka.
content.en: The chief of the Aukaners.

content.srn: Mi masra famiri oso.
content.en: My husband’s family’s house.

content.srn: Mi de na mi mama oso.
content.en: I’m at my mother’s house.

content.srn: Mi e go na mi mama oso.
content.en: I’m going to my mother’s house.

content.srn: A bedi de na ini a kamra.
content.en: The bed is in the room.

content.srn: A bedi de na a karma ini.
content.en: The bed is in the room

content.srn: Nanga wantu mati fu mi.
content.en: With some friends of mine.

content.srn: Ini a yari fu 1492.
content.en: In the year 1492.

content.srn: Na ini Sranan.
content.en: In Sranan.

content.srn: Dis' wiki.
content.en: This week.

content.srn: A man di gi mi a papira.
content.en: The man who gave me the paper.

content.srn: A tori disi san mi e go taki.
content.en: The story that I’m going to tell.

content.srn: A liba disi bradi tumsi fu swen abra.
content.en: This river is too broad to swim across.

content.srn: A watra faya bun.
content.en: The water is very hot.

content.srn: A oloisi disi diri moro a dati.
content.en: This watch is more expensive than that one.

content.srn: John moro bigi.
content.en: John's bigger.

content.srn: A oloisi disi moro diri.
content.en: This watch is more expensive.

content.srn: A liba de tumsi bradi fu swen abra.
content.en: The river is too broad to swim across.

content.srn: A watra de bun faya.
content.en: The water is very hot.

content.srn: John de moro bigi leki Peter.
content.en: John’s bigger than Peter.

content.srn: Dati na a triki fu en.
content.en: That’s his trick.

content.srn: Den si den ingi.
content.en: They saw the Indians.

content.srn: Dati a wan nengre leki den srefi.
content.en: That is a black man like themselves.

content.srn: Fa a kon dati alaten yu e kon lati na wroko.
content.en: How is it that you always come late to work?

content.srn: Ala yuru a man disi e kon tanteri mi.
content.en: This man comes and bothers me all the time.

content.srn: Mi bari en nofotron fu no waka nanga den boi dati.
content.en: I warned him often not to hang around with those boys.

content.srn: Mi bari a pikin nofotron fu no waka nanga den boi dati.
content.en: I warned the child often not to hang around with those boys.

content.srn: San yu tyari kon gi mi?
content.en: What did you bring for me?

content.srn: A de bun.
content.en: He/She/It is good/well.

content.srn: En na mi mati.
content.en: He/She is my friend.

content.srn: Na en teki a buku.
content.en: It’s HER/HIM that took the book.

content.srn: Wi e kon dalék.
content.en: We're coming right away.

content.srn: Mi heri famiri kon na a friyari-oso.
content.en: My whole family came to the birthday party.

content.srn: Un prisiri sote!
content.en: We really enjoyed ourselves.

content.srn: Mi nanga Arnie e tan ini a srefi birti.
content.en: Arnie and I live in the same neighborhood.

content.srn: Wan sma e waka ini a strati.
content.en: Someone walks in the street.

content.srn: A gersi sani e dringi mi brudu.
content.en: It's like something is drinking my blood.

content.srn: Den oso.
content.en: The houses.

content.srn: Den uma.
content.en: The women.

content.srn: Den meki tumsi opo-opo.
content.en: They made a big fuss.

content.srn: Norfu e férfi férfi.
content.en: Norval is painting a bit.

content.srn: A oso de férfi férfi
content.en: The house is (in a) painted (state).

content.srn: A oso férfi ferfi
content.en: The house was/has been painted several times.

content.srn: Esde mi drai mi futu.
content.en: Yesterday I twisted my foot.

content.srn: Den ten disi a son e faya.
content.en: These days the sun is hot.

content.srn: Ma dan fa a sani dati du kon dan eigenlijk dan.
content.en: But how did that actually happen?

content.srn: Wan ben tron datra srefi.
content.en: One even became a doctor.

content.srn: No wan sma ben bai den nyanyan.
content.en: Not one person bought them.

content.srn: Dus no wan, no wan fu unu ben man bai a unusrefi.
content.en: So none of us could buy from each other.

content.srn: Nanga den sma disi wi o abi wan taki-makandra.
content.en: We will have a conversation with these people.

content.srn: Fowru e singi, dagu e bari.
content.en: Birds sing, dogs bark

content.srn: A man dati kon dri leisi dya.
content.en: That man came here three times.

content.srn: A man disi sabi a tori.
content.en: This guy knows the story.

content.srn: Disi a fu un bori.
content.en: This is for us to cook.

content.srn: Dati meki mi no ben kisi brede a skoro.
content.en: That’s why I didn’t get bread in school.

content.srn: Mi begi, yu no kan fergiti dati tog.
content.en: I prayed, you can’t forget that, right.

content.srn: A man disi.
content.en: This man.

content.srn: A man dati.
content.en: Than man.

content.srn: Fosi.
content.en: First.

content.srn: Di fu tu.
content.en: Second.

content.srn: Di fu feifi.
content.en: Fifth.

content.srn: A uma siki moro en sisa.
content.en: The woman’s more ill than her sister.

content.srn: Mi futu no de so bigi.
content.en: My feet are not so big.

content.srn: O bigi yu futu de?
content.en: How big is your foot?

content.srn: Dan a no man nanga a ouderwets sani fu en.
content.en: Then he can’t put up with her old-fashioned ways.

content.srn: Den tu pikin fu mi lobi fu nyan bami.
content.en: My two children love to eat bami.

content.srn: A plan fu a Masra e go doro.
content.en: The Lord’s plan continues.

content.srn: Ma fa a pikin fu Oom N du dede dan?
content.en: But how did Uncle N’s child actually die, then?

content.srn: Den bigi suma taki yu kan kibri yu granmama bere.
content.en: The older folk say you can hide your grandmother’s belly.

content.srn: Ma yu no kan kibri granmama koso.
content.en: But you can’t hide grandma's coughing.

content.srn: A buku disi na fu mi.
content.en: This book is mine.

content.srn: A oto na fu en.
content.en: The car is his.

content.srn: John bigi moro Peter.
content.en: John’s bigger than Peter.

content.srn: Amba tranga pasa Kofi.
content.en: Amba is stronger than Kofi.

content.srn: John moro bigi moro Peter.
content.en: John is taller than Peter.

content.srn: A oloisi disi moro diri moro a dati.
content.en: This watch is more expensive than that one.

content.srn: Kofi bigi moro leki Kwaku.
content.en: Kofi is bigger than Kwaku.

content.srn: Efu mi ben gudu, mi ben sa bai wan oto.
content.en: If I were rich, I would buy a car.

content.srn: Nownow de Tanti M sa ben e ferteri stori efu a ben de na libi ete.
content.en: Aunt M would have been telling stories right now if she were still alive.

content.srn: Wel, dan granpa ben sa e gi den (owru tori) ma dati mi no miti.
content.en: Well, then granddad would have (habitually) told them, but I never experienced that.

content.srn: Efu John ben de dya, a ben sa e sribi now.
content.en: If John were here, he would be sleeping now.

content.srn: A ben musu e taki nanga en m’ma.
content.en: She must have been talking to her mother.

content.srn: Te prani aleisi ten, mi ben e gwe go prani aleisi.
content.en: When it was time to plant rice, I went to plant rice.

content.srn: Dus suma pikin e musu meki muyti.
content.en: So the children must do their best.

content.srn: Ma yu no e man onthou ala den tori so moro.
content.en: But you can't remember all the stories anymore.

content.srn: En efu a man dati wini en, a kondre e kon bun zeker.
content.en: And if that man wins it [the election] the country will surely improve.

content.srn: Mi e sidon dya, mi e denki fu beroof wan bangi now de.
content.en: I’m sitting here thinking to rob a bank right now.

content.srn: Den man e pina, yungu.
content.en: Those people are suffering, man.

content.srn: Yu no e sabi a wet so bun.
content.en: You don’t really know the law so well.

content.srn: Den e afrontu den tongo, tog.
content.en: They turn their backs on their language, right.

content.srn: Den no e wani taki Sranan Tongo moro.
content.en: They don't want to speak Sranan Tongo anymore.

content.srn: Efu pikinso wan druppel nomo kisi yu skin, yu skin e bron.
content.en: If even so much as a drop touches your skin, it burns.

content.srn: Den ben lafu unu taki unu no ben gwenti si trein.
content.en: They laughed at us saying that we weren’t used to seeing trains.

content.srn: A pikin e krin en kamra.
content.en: The child is cleaning her room.

content.srn: A man wani taki den kaw musu go pupe.
content.en: The man wanted the cows to relieve themselves.

content.srn: Efu yu no wroko, dan you no o nyan, tog.
content.en: If you don’t work, then you won’t eat, right?

content.srn: Ma yu no musu du den sani dati.
content.en: But you mustn’t do those things.

content.srn: Esde di mi kon na oso a ben e skrifi wan brifi.
content.en: Yesterday when I came to the house, he was writing a letter.

content.srn: Di mi kon na oso esde a ben skrifi tu brifi kaba.
content.en: When I came to the house yesterday, he had already written two letters.

content.srn: A e skrifi wan brifi.
content.en: She’s writing a letter.

content.srn: A musu de taki na den pikin nyan a kuku.
content.en: It must be the case that it was the children who ate the cake.

content.srn: A pikin wani go sribi.
content.en: The child wants to go and sleep.

content.srn: A kamra kowru bikaa mi opo a fensre.
content.en: The room is cold because I opened the window.

content.srn: Safrisafri mi e sabi den pasi kba.
content.en: I’m slowly getting to know the roads.

content.srn: A manya e lepi.
content.en: The mango is getting ripe.

content.srn: A pikin e kon breiti.
content.en: The child is becoming happy.

content.srn: A e waka na foto e seri krosi.
content.en: He walks around in town selling clothes.

content.srn: Kande Jan ben sribi kaba.
content.en: Perhaps John was already asleep.

content.srn: Den kan e wakti unu na oso.
content.en: They may be awaiting us at home.

content.srn: A kan de taki Jan ben sribi kaba.
content.en: It’s possible that John was already asleep.

content.srn: Mi kan go na dansi bikasi mi abi moni.
content.en: I can go to the dance because I have money.

content.srn: No naki en!
content.en: Don’t hit it!

content.srn: Unu no naki en!
content.en: Don’t you guys hit it!

content.srn: A no e naki en.
content.en: He doesn’t hit it.

content.srn: Naki en!
content.en: Hit it!

content.srn: So den losi pom nanga kuku nanga ala den sortu sani.
content.en: That’s how they baked pom and cake and all that stuff.

content.srn: Den nyan ala den gansi!
content.en: They ate all the geese.

content.srn: Den nyan unu sturu bij.
content.en: They even ate our chairs.

content.srn: Den agu nyan den beest?
content.en: The pigs ate the geese?

content.srn: Ma dan den meti no lon gwe?
content.en: But didn’t the geese run away?

content.srn: A kon mangri.
content.en: He’s gotten skinny.

content.srn: Mi e teki en poti ini a pan.
content.en: I take it and put it in the pan.

content.srn: En nanga trawan kon dya nanga wan bigi sipi.
content.en: He and others came here on a big ship.

content.srn: Kande en srefi e kon na foto bori a agu gi mi.
content.en: Perhaps he himself comes to the city to cook the pig for me.

content.srn: Mi gi a san disi wan nen.
content.en: I gave this thing a name.

content.srn: Granmama gi den pikin tori fa a ben de fosten.
content.en: Grandmother told the children stories about how it was in the old days.

content.srn: Dus dan a mati o gi den suma fu en a tori.
content.en: So then the friend will tell his relatives the story.

content.srn: A trawan gi a boi, gi a tra boi feifi, a vijfhonderd.
content.en: The other one gave the boy, gave the boy five, the five hundred.

content.srn: Unu no kan gi den man a disi.
content.en: You can’t give them these.

content.srn: Dus den musu gi mi furu watra fu mi dringi.
content.en: So they need to give me a lot of water to drink.

content.srn: A de bun.
content.en: He/She/It is good/well.

content.srn: Mi no wani taki nanga yu.
content.en: I don’t want to talk to you.

content.srn: Yu si, unu de bezig bouw a stal drape moro bun.
content.en: You see, we’re busy making the stall there better.

content.srn: Ma a gersi taki den kuli wani teki a kondre now op yungu.
content.en: But it seems that the Hindustanis want to take over the country now, man

content.srn: Mi taki dan a gersi leki mi dede kba.
content.en: I said, “Then it looks like I’m already dead.”

content.srn: Merki no de srefisrefi a foto.
content.en: There isn’t any milk at all in town.

content.srn: En sontron te unu kmopo a skoro alen e kon.
content.en: And sometimes when we came from school it rained.

content.srn: Dan mi taki ai, a no pikinso alen fadon.
content.en: Then I said, ‘well, it rained a lot.' (Lit. 'it wasn't just a little rain that fell')

content.srn: A alen wai pikinso.
content.en: The rain has blown away a little (i.e.: It’s not raining so hard anymore.)

content.srn: Mi ede span span wan sortu fasi.
content.en: I have some sort of a headache.

content.srn: Mi weri.
content.en: I’m tired.

content.srn: Ede-hati e kiri mi.
content.en: A headache is killing me.

content.srn: So ma dan mi bigin lobi a sani kba.
content.en: So, but then I began to like the thing.

content.srn: Mi lobi pley bal.
content.en: I like to play football (soccer).

content.srn: A frow lobi go a Holland.
content.en: His wife likes to go to the Netherlands.

content.srn: A man e frede a kaaiman.
content.en: He’s afraid of the crocodile.

content.srn: Wan leisi mi si wan weri ede sani ma mi no e frede, yere.
content.en: Once I saw something horrible, but I was not scared.

content.srn: Mi frede, yu go tapu en.
content.en: I’m scared, you go and close it.

content.srn: Kofi teki a nefi koti a brede.
content.en: Kofi cut the bread with a knife.

content.srn: Boi, teki a tin sensi dya go bai tabaka gi mi.
content.en: Boy, take this dime and go and get me some tobacco.

content.srn: Kande a taigi yu meki yu furu a heri bari nanga watra, dan yu abi fu go teki watra drape a mofo gotro, lai a bari.
content.en: Maybe she will tell you to fill the whole barrel with water, then you have to go take water from in front of the ditch and fill the barrel.

content.srn: So wan leisi a naki mi nanga wan batra.
content.en: So one time she hit me with a bottle.

content.srn: Yu kan tapu en nanga wan planga.
content.en: You can close it with a plank.

content.srn: Dus dan so unu ben kon a foto nanga a bigi boto.
content.en: So that’s how we came to Paramaribo on the big ship.

content.srn: Dan fakansi ten dan wi e go nanga wan heri groep.
content.en: During the vacation we went with the entire group.

content.srn: Mi go nanga mi brada na foto.
content.en: I went to town with my brother.

content.srn: Te mi ppa e wroko dan, den e gwe nanga en.
content.en: When my father went to work then they would go with him.

content.srn: A e teki den tyari gwe go, go drai miri.
content.en: He would take them along to go turn the mill.

content.srn: Anansi ben prei wan triki nanga Kakalaka nanga Kafowru.
content.en: Anansi played a trick on Cockroach and Chicken.

content.srn: Tyari a karaaf nanga wan kan gi mi.
content.en: Fetch the pitcher and a can for me.

content.srn: Yu e go na a mma dan yu o taki.
content.en: You’d go to the mother and you’d speak.

content.srn: Boiki papa ben prani gruntu èn a ben kewki fowru nanga wan kaw.
content.en: Boiki’s father grew vegetables, and he raised chickens and a cow.

content.srn: Den tu sma disi na Sranansma.
content.en: These two people are Surinamese.

content.srn: Den tu man na skowtu.
content.en: The two men are policemen.

content.srn: A liba bradi.
content.en: The river is wide.

content.srn: A pikin siki.
content.en: The child is ill.

content.srn: A bun.
content.en: It's good/okay.

content.srn: A ma dati srefi de vol.
content.en: That mother (cow) herself is pregnant

content.srn: A agu dati de moi kaba.
content.en: That pig is already nice and fat.

content.srn: Den pikin ben de na skoro.
content.en: The children were at school.

content.srn: A owru de baka a doro.
content.en: The machete is behind the door.

content.srn: A boi fu dya bakasey no drape moro?
content.en: The guy in the back is not there anymore?

content.srn: Mi prakseri a boi disi nanga a man dati musu de brada.
content.en: I think this boy and that man must be brothers.

content.srn: Yu sabi Dark Shadow ben de wan frede film.
content.en: You know Dark Shadow was a scary movie.

content.srn: Ma Sjo srefi ben de datisei.
content.en: But Sjo himself was from that area.

content.srn: Yungu, yu no abi ai fu si?
content.en: Boy, don’t you have eyes?

content.srn: Efu yu no abi flashlait efu munkenki, yu no e si.
content.en: If you didn’t have a flashlight or moonlight, you couldn’t see.

content.srn: Te wan mama abi pikin kba, a pikin musu nyan.
content.en: When a mother has a child, the child must eat.

content.srn: Mi no abi a bribi dati.
content.en: I don’t believe so.

content.srn: Pe wan pikin nengre de, zegen nanga blesi de ini a oso dati.
content.en: Where there’s a child, there are blessings in that house.

content.srn: Mi no abi televisi na oso.
content.en: I don’t have TV at home.

content.srn: Yu abi furu Sumter di mi no sabi.
content.en: There are many people by the name of Sumter that I don’t know.

content.srn: Den abi wan singi e singi taki lespeki no de moro.
content.en: There’s a song that says that there’s no respect anymore.

content.srn: Dan mi post dri go na Holland.
content.en: Then I mailed three to Holland.

content.srn: Yu ben go nanga trein na Republiek.
content.en: You went by train to Republiek.

content.srn: A blaka man kari a ingi taki kon unu go na Kwatta pasi.
content.en: The black guy called the Indian saying let’s go to Kwatta street.

content.srn: En a man taki te a man go a Holland dan a man o seni wan sani gi mi.
content.en: And the man said that when he went to Holland he would send something for me.

content.srn: Yu yere dati Turku e suku yu, a betre yu wijk uit komoto na Holland.
content.en: You hear that the Turks are looking for you, you better get out of Holland.

content.srn: A granman fu den Dyuka kmopo fu Dritabiki.
content.en: The chief of the Aukeners comes from Drietabbetje.

content.srn: Den pikin e go na skoro.
content.en: The children go to school.

content.srn: A no e denki fu kon baka na oso.
content.en: It hasn’t crossed her mind to come back home.

content.srn: Te den pranasi sma ben kmopo fu tapusei kon nanga boto.
content.en: When the people of the plantation came from upriver by boat.

content.srn: Di a bromfiets lon drei, mi ben abi fu pusu en go na oso.
content.en: When the motorbike ran out of gas, I had to push it home.

content.srn: Skoifi a kasi go ini a uku.
content.en: Push the cabinet into the corner.

content.srn: Kofi hari a ston puru na ini a olo.
content.en: Kofi pulled the stone out of the hole.

content.srn: Kofi hari a pikin komoto na ini a olo.
content.en: Kofi pulled the child out of the hole.

content.srn: Yu kan tyari wan suma go a wan tehuis.
content.en: You can take someone to a nursing home.

content.srn: A ben rij kon na post na mi tog, tra dei tog, tra esde.
content.en: He had come to me at the station the other day, the day before yesterday.

content.srn: A man teki swarfu dosu fringi naki.
content.en: The man takes the matchbox and throws it and hits.

content.srn: Kande a man teki omeni poti ini en saka kba.
content.en: Maybe the man took a lot for his own pocket already.

content.srn: Mi papa e teki moro furu aandacht gi a man.
content.en: My father pays more attention to the man.

content.srn: Hey, den man, den man e teki a sani e meki grap.
content.en: Hey, they are making the joke of the matter.

content.srn: Bori pikin supu gi ma Akuba nanga pikin Anansi.
content.en: Cook a little soup for mother Akuba and little spider.

content.srn: Mi seri a oso gi en.
content.en: I sold the house to him/her.

content.srn: No, a kil musu du wan sani gi mi ini a gare.
content.en: No, the man has to do something for me in the house.

content.srn: A koti ensrefi nanga wan nefi.
content.en: He cut himself with a knife.

content.srn: A ten di a kisi en srefi taki a ben musu gwe nanga a kromanti.
content.en: When he realized that, he had to go away with the spirit.

content.srn: Mi srefi dya abi famiri mi no sabi.
content.en: I myself have relatives that I don’t know.

content.srn: Skowtu srefi no sabi suma fufuru a wagi.
content.en: Even the police don’t know who stole the car.

content.srn: Den srudati feti nanga densrefi.
content.en: The soldiers fought with each other.

content.srn: Den lobi densrefi tumsi.
content.en: They love themselves too much.

content.srn: Den brasa makandra.
content.en: They hugged each other.

content.srn: Kande den suma disi ben kweki tra fasi.
content.en: Maybe these people were raised differently.

content.srn: A liba bradi kba.
content.en: The river has already been widened.

content.srn: A krosi e krin.
content.en: The clothes are being cleaned.

content.srn: A libi di ben de a fosi nanga di fu now papa a no wan.
content.en: Life today is different from that of the days gone by.

content.srn: A sani di de nownow unu no man tyari.
content.en: What we now have is tough to bear.

content.srn: Dan den suma san e libi dyaso o abi fu teki ala a wroko.
content.en: Then the people that live here will have to do all the work.

content.srn: Den man san e meki na kondre kon sani.
content.en: The men that are causing the country to become the way it is.

content.srn: Yu sabi wan boi ben de na skowtu den e kari en Oscar?
content.en: Do you know a guy named Oscar who was a police officer?

content.srn: Dus dan a man kon ferstan taki na frow san a wasi.
content.en: So then the man understood that it was the woman whom he had washed.

content.srn: Mi e wani go libi nanga a man di mi o sori yu.
content.en: I want to go and live with the person that I’ll show you.

content.srn: Wan bigi man ben wroko dape di den e kari papa Mani.
content.en: An elderly man worked there whom they called papa Mani.

content.srn: Dan a man di mi nanga en e taki...
content.en: Then the man who I was talking to...

content.srn: A nefi nanga san a koti a bred.
content.en: The knife with which he cut the bread.

content.srn: Nanga san yu koti a brede?
content.en: What did you cut the bread with?

content.srn: Den boi taki dati den o kon tamara baka.
content.en: The boys said that they would come back tomorrow.

content.srn: A bonuman taigi a frow taki a musu weri wan bereketi fu kan kon betre.
content.en: The medicine man told the woman that she had to wear a chain around her waist in order to get better.

content.srn: Dan Anansi taki, en go proberi efi en kan sabi fa a nen.
content.en: Then Anansi said he would try if he could learn his name.

content.srn: Mi bribi a man gwe na Holland volgens mi, yere.
content.en: I believe he’s gone to Holland.

content.srn: A no ben sab' taki na wan bigi Anansi.
content.en: He did not know that this was a grown-up Anansi.

content.srn: Di mi si dati a susu no e fiti mi, mi tyari en go kenki.
content.en: When I realized that the shoes didn't fit me, I went and exchanged them.

content.srn: Jan wani fu kisi moni.
content.en: Jan wants to make money.

content.srn: Yu denki taki na ala sma o gi bun sani.
content.en: You think that everyone will give good (spirits).

content.srn: Dati ede den no wani mi taki.
content.en: Therefore they don't want me to talk.

content.srn: Mi denki yu kaba nanga en.
content.en: I thought you were done with it.

content.srn: Fa un doro un bigin wroko.
content.en: As soon as we arrived, we began to work.

content.srn: Di mi doro na oso esde, mi brada gi mi moni.
content.en: When I got home yesterday, my brother gave me money.

content.srn: En te den man dati e kon tapu a strati, dan den e law.
content.en: And when those guys come out on the street, they go crazy.

content.srn: Mi no si en esde.
content.en: I didn’t see him yesterday.

content.srn: A diri k’farlek, yu no man bai en.
content.en: It’s terribly expensive, you can’t buy it.

content.srn: Mi no feni en, mi no feni a fopper.
content.en: I haven’t found it, I haven’t found the pacifier.

content.srn: No wan suma no man verklaar yu wan oorlog tori.
content.en: No one can tell you war stories.

content.srn: Yu no abi fu abi noti.
content.en: You don’t have to have any.

content.srn: Noti no pasa nanga mi.
content.en: Nothing happened to me.

content.srn: Oh, ma dan a ben kan kon taki now, tog?
content.en: Oh, but then he could come and chat now, right?

content.srn: A film ben span, no?
content.en: The movie was exciting, wasn’t it?

content.srn: Yu no musu sabi wan fosi ten tori?
content.en: Surely you know an old time story?

content.srn: Nownow yu e teki en kba nownow?
content.en: Are you already recording it right now?

content.srn: Na yu fufuru mi moni!
content.en: It’s you that stole my money.

content.srn: Na leriman a man de.
content.en: The man’s a teacher.

content.srn: Want na tu leisi mi nanga a man meki afsprak kaba.
content.en: Because it’s twice that the guy and I made an appointment already.

content.srn: A musu de feti den ben feti, yu sabi.
content.en: They must have been fighting, you know.

content.srn: A stik yu o stik a pikin.
content.en: You’ll suffocate the child this way.

content.srn: Na kon yu e kon fu teki a moni kba?
content.en: You’ve come already to take the money?

content.srn: Yu srefi tu musu dyompu nanga wan, yu begrijp.
content.en: You too must jump with one [foot] you understand.

content.srn: Mi tu no erken, dati meki mi e tyari Miller.
content.en: I too wasn’t acknowledged (as someone’s child), that’s why I go by the name of Miller.

content.srn: I mu yepi wroko tu.
content.en: You, too, must help with the work.

content.srn: Na so mi ben tyari mi srefi tu.
content.en: That’s how I, too, behaved.

content.srn: We, yere dya.
content.en: Hey, listen here.

content.srn: Gilly, kon yere.
content.en: Gilly, come hear [this].

content.srn: A kon, a langa en mofo, a man meki wan tyuri, dan a gwe.
content.en: He came, he pouted, the guy made a ‘suck teeth’ and went away.

content.srn: Ma fosi, yu ben abi wan wan sma di o du a sani dati, ma te yu meki a tyuri now, dan a bigi sma kan teki yu gewoon dan a fon yu.
content.en: But before, you had a few people who did that, but if you made the 'sucking_sound_with_your_lips' now then the older person would just take you and give you a beating.

content.srn: Mi broko mi anu di mi dyompo kmopo fu a bon.
content.en: I broke my arm when I jumped out of the tree.

content.srn: Fa mi broko mi finga, mi no man knopo mi empi.
content.en: Because I broke my finger, I cannot button my shirt.

content.srn: Mi e kan mi wiwiri mamanten yuru fosi mi e go na doro.
content.en: I comb my hair in the morning before going out.

content.srn: Smeri a nyanyan gi mi efu a no swa.
content.en: Smell the food for me to see if it is spoiled.

content.srn: I n'e yere?
content.en: Can't you hear?
